name: LHS 1140
scenarioDescription:
The LHS 1140 Exoplanetary System


Overview

LHS 1140 is a star with 0.18 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.21 times its radius. It is located 48.890784399999994 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 5 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

LHS 1140 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the LHS 1140 system

LHS 1140 c

LHS 1140 c was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the Transit method. The mass of LHS 1140 c is 1.81 times the mass of Earth. The radius of LHS 1140 c is 1.282 that of Earth. At 1.81 Earth masses, LHS 1140 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


LHS 1140 b

LHS 1140 b was discovered by the MEarth Project observatory using the Transit method. The mass of LHS 1140 b is 6.98 times the mass of Earth. The radius of LHS 1140 b is 1.727 that of Earth. At 6.98 Earth masses, LHS 1140 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system LHS 1140, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Multiple Observatories.
